This guide will focus on a programming approach using Python, which is beginner-friendly. \\\\n\\\\n### Step 1: Set Up Your Environment\\\\n\\\\n1. **Install Python**:\\\\n   - Visit the \x5bPython official website\x5d(https:\/\/www.python.org\/downloads\/) and download the latest version of Python.\\\\n   - Follow the installation instructions for your operating system.\\\\n\\\\n2. **Install Required Libraries**:\\\\n   - Open your command prompt or terminal and install the required libraries by running the following commands:\\\\n     ```bash\\\\n     pip install requests\\\\n     ```\\\\n\\\\n### Step 2: Get Google Keep API Access\\\\n\\\x22,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22is\\\x22\x7d\x5d\x5d\x5d\x22,\x22checkedCheckboxesCount\x22:\x220\x22,\x22hasContent\x22:true\x7d,\x22indexableText\x22:\x22Here\x27s a detailed step-by-step guide to help you set up an automated workflow between Google Keep and Notion using their APIs. This guide will focus on a programming approach using Python, which is beginner-friendly. \\n\\n### Step 1: Set Up Your Environment\\n\\n1. **Install Python**:\\n   - Visit the \x5bPython official website\x5d(https:\/\/www.python.org\/downloads\/) and download the latest version of Python.\\n   - Follow the installation instructions for your operating system.\\n\\n2. **Install Required Libraries**:\\n   - Open your command prompt or terminal and install the required libraries by running the following commands:\\n     ```bash\\n     pip install requests\\n     ```\\n\\n### Step 2: Get Google Keep API Access\\n\\nGoogle Keep does not have a direct public API. However, you can use the unofficial `gkeepapi` library.\\n\\n1. **Install gkeepapi**:\\n   ```bash\\n   pip install gkeepapi\\n   ```\\n\\n2. **Authenticate with Google**:\\n   - You\x27ll need to use your Google account to authorise access. The `gkeepapi` library requires you to log in through your credentials.\\n\\n### Step 3: Get Notion API Access\\n\\n1. **Create a Notion Integration**:\\n   - Go to \x5bNotion Developers\x5d(https:\/\/www.notion.so\/my-integrations) and click on \\\x22New integration\\\x22.\\n   - Fill in the required details and save the integration. Note down the **Integration Token**.\\n\\n2. **Share a Database with your Integration**:\\n   - Create a page or a database in Notion.\\n   - Share it with the integration you just created by clicking \\\x22Share\\\x22 and adding your integration.\\n\\n### Step 4: Write the Python Script\\n\\nHere’s a basic Python script to fetch notes from Google Keep and send them to Notion:\\n\\n```python\\nimport gkeepapi\\nimport requests\\n\\n# Google Keep Login\\nkeep \x3d gkeepapi.Keep()\\nkeep.login(\x27your_google_email@gmail.com\x27, \x27your_google_password\x27)  # Replace with your credentials\\n\\n# Fetch notes\\nnotes \x3d keep.all()\\n\\n# Notion API Information\\nnotion_url \x3d \x27https:\/\/api.notion.com\/v1\/pages\x27\\nnotion_token \x3d \x27your_notion_integration_token\x27  # Replace with your Notion Integration Token\\nnotion_database_id \x3d \x27your_database_id\x27  # Replace with your Notion Database ID\\n\\n# Notion Headers\\nheaders \x3d \x7b\\n    \\\x22Authorization\\\x22: f\\\x22Bearer \x7bnotion_token\x7d\\\x22,\\n    \\\x22Notion-Version\\\x22: \\\x222021-05-13\\\x22,\\n    \\\x22Content-Type\\\x22: \\\x22application\/json\\\x22\\n\x7d\\n\\nfor note in notes:\\n    if note.archived:  # Skip archived notes\\n        continue\\n    \\n    # Construct the page content for Notion\\n    page_data \x3d \x7b\\n        \\\x22parent\\\x22: \x7b \\\x22id\\\x22: notion_database_id \x7d,\\n        \\\x22properties\\\x22: \x7b\\n            \\\x22Name\\\x22: \x7b\\n                \\\x22title\\\x22: \x5b\\n                    \x7b\\n                        \\\x22text\\\x22: \x7b\\n                            \\\x22content\\\x22: note.title\\n                        \x7d\\n                    \x7d\\n                \x5d\\n            \x7d,\\n            \\\x22Content\\\x22: \x7b\\n                \\\x22rich_text\\\x22: \x5b\\n                    \x7b\\n                        \\\x22text\\\x22: \x7b\\n                            \\\x22content\\\x22: note.text\\n                        \x7d\\n                    \x7d\\n                \x5d\\n            \x7d\\n        \x7d\\n    \x7d\\n\\n    # Send a request to Notion API to create a new page\\n    response \x3d requests.post(notion_url, headers\x3dheaders, json\x3dpage_data)\\n    \\n    if response.status_code \x3d\x3d 200:\\n        print(f\x27Successfully added note: \x7bnote.title\x7d\x27)\\n    else:\\n        print(f\x27Failed to add note: \x7bnote.title\x7d with error: \x27, response.content)\\n\\n```\\n\\n### Step 5: Run Your Script\\n\\n1. **Modify the Script**:\\n   - Replace `your_google_email@gmail.com`, `your_google_password`, `your_notion_integration_token`, and `your_database_id` with your actual credentials and information.\\n\\n2. **Run the Script**:\\n   - Save the script in a file named `keep_to_notion.py`, and run it via the command line using:\\n     ```bash\\n     python keep_to_notion.py\\n     ```\\n\\n### Step 6: Automate Your Workflow\\n\\nTo automate the script, you can schedule it to run periodically:\\n\\n- **Windows**: Use Task Scheduler to run the script at a specific time.\\n- **macOS\/Linux**: Set up a cron job to run the script at intervals.\\n\\n### Additional Tips\\n\\n- **Security**: Consider using environment variables or a secure vault for your credentials instead of hardcoding them in the script.\\n- **Error Handling**: Enhance the script with more sophisticated error handling as you become more comfortable with Python.\\n- **Explore API Documentation**: Familiarize yourself with the \x5bGoogle Keep API documentation\x5d(https:\/\/github.com\/kiwibbt\/gkeepapi) and \x5bNotion API documentation\x5d(https:\/\/developers.notion.com\/docs) for more advanced features.\\n\\nBy following these steps, you should be able to create a functional workflow to transfer your notes from Google Keep to Notion using APIs. t-add\\\x22,0,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22,\\\x22txt\\\x22\x5d,\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22ibi\\\x22:1,\\\x22s\\\x22:\\\x22Thank you for the feedback! I\\\\u2019m thrilled to expand on the opportunity to lead a micro-credentialing initiative in the multidisciplinary space, focusing on mentorship in medical supervision within Australian general practice. This expansion will integrate supervision of practice nurses, allied health trainees (e.g., pharmacists, physiotherapists, dietitians), and other multidisciplinary team members, drawing from the general practice context. Below, I\\\\u2019ll revise and enhance the briefing note, course structure, and case studies\/role-plays to reflect this broader scope, ensuring relevance to the Australian healthcare system, particularly primary care. The response maintains a professional yet conversational tone, uses Australian spelling, and adheres to Harvard referencing style.\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n### Part 1: Revised Briefing Note on Developing Educational Materials for Mentorship in Medical Supervision (2025-26)\\\\n\\\\n**Title: Leading a Micro-Credential Initiative in Multidisciplinary Mentorship for Medical Supervision in Australian General Practice**\\\\n\\\\n**Introduction**\\\\n\\\\nMentorship in medical supervision is pivotal in shaping competent, confident healthcare professionals across disciplines in Australian general practice. As primary healthcare evolves into a multidisciplinary model, general practices increasingly rely on diverse teams, including general practitioners (GPs), practice nurses, allied health professionals (e.g., pharmacists, physiotherapists, dietitians), and non-clinical staff (e.g., practice managers). These teams collectively support medical students, prevocational doctors, GP registrars, nursing students, and allied health trainees. A micro-credentialing course targeting mentorship in this multidisciplinary context offers a unique opportunity to lead professional development in Australian primary care. This briefing note explores the viability of developing a 2025-26 online micro-credential course, incorporating a market analysis, evidence-based recommendations, and a focus on multidisciplinary supervision, grounded in peer-reviewed literature tailored to general practice.\\\\n\\\\n**Rationale for a Multidisciplinary Micro-Credential**\\\\n\\\\nGeneral practice in Australia is a hub for multidisciplinary care, with practices employing or collaborating with practice nurses, allied health professionals, and non-clinical staff to deliver holistic patient care (Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, 2025). Mentorship in this context extends beyond traditional GP supervision to include guiding nursing students, allied health trainees, and prevocational doctors through clinical and professional development. The Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (AHPRA) and the Australian Medical Council (AMC) emphasise the importance of supervision in ensuring safe, competent practice across disciplines (AHPRA, 2024; Australian Medical Council, 2024). However, supervisors often lack formal training in mentoring diverse learners, particularly in navigating the unique roles of practice nurses (e.g., chronic disease management) and allied health trainees (e.g., interprofessional collaboration) (Halcomb et al., 2017).\\\\n\\\\nThe multidisciplinary nature of general practice presents both challenges and opportunities. Practice nurses, for instance, require supervision that balances clinical skills with patient education, while allied health trainees need guidance on integrating their expertise into primary care workflows (Schutze, Bennett and McKelvey, 2022). Non-clinical staff play a critical role in fostering a supportive practice culture, yet they are rarely included in mentorship training (Mills, Francis and Bonner, 2005). A micro-credential course addressing these needs can standardise mentorship practices, enhance interprofessional collaboration, and improve learner and patient outcomes, particularly in rural and remote settings where multidisciplinary teams are vital (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, 2024).\\\\n\\\x22,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22is\\\x22\x7d\x5d\x5d\x22,\x22\x5b\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22ibi\\\x22:3971,\\\x22s\\\x22:\\\x22\\\\n**Market Analysis of Online Courses on Medical Supervision**\\\\n\\\\nThe market for online healthcare education in Australia is expanding, driven by the need for accessible, accredited professional development. Below is an updated analysis of existing offerings, with a focus on multidisciplinary supervision:\\\\n\\\\n1. **RACGP Mentoring Program**  \\\\n   The RACGP\\\\u2019s mentoring program supports early-career GPs but does not address practice nurses or allied health trainees (RACGP, 2025). It lacks a multidisciplinary focus and is not a micro-credential, limiting its applicability to diverse teams.\\\\n\\\\n2. **Ausmed Preceptorship and Mentoring Course**  \\\\n   Ausmed\\\\u2019s 1.2-hour CPD course targets nurses and healthcare professionals but is not specific to general practice or allied health supervision (Ausmed, 2024). Its short duration and lack of micro-credential certification limit its depth and appeal for multidisciplinary learners.\\\\n\\\\n3. **Australian College of Nursing (ACN) Preceptor Program**  \\\\n   The ACN offers a preceptor program for nurses, focusing on clinical supervision (Australian College of Nursing, 2025). While relevant for practice nurses, it excludes allied health and non-clinical staff and is not tailored to the general practice context.\\\\n\\\\n4. **Allied Health Professions Australia (AHPA) Mentoring Resources**  \\\\n   AHPA provides mentoring guidelines for allied health professionals but lacks a structured online course or micro-credential (AHPA, 2024). It does not address the general practice setting or interprofessional supervision.\\\\n\\\\n5. **UNSW Medicine Clinical Mentoring Scheme**  \\\\n   UNSW\\\\u2019s scheme focuses on medical students and clinicians, not practice nurses or allied health trainees (UNSW Medicine, 2025). It is not online and lacks a multidisciplinary focus.\\\\n\\\\n6. **Global Health Education (GHE) Postgraduate Courses**  \\\\n   GHE\\\\u2019s postgraduate courses include mentorship components but are lengthy and not specific to general practice or multidisciplinary teams (Global Health Education, 2025). They are not micro-credentials, reducing accessibility.\\\\n\\\\n**Market Gaps and Opportunities**  \\\\n- **Multidisciplinary Focus**: No existing course comprehensively addresses mentorship for GPs, practice nurses, allied health trainees, and non-clinical staff in general practice.  \\\\n- **General Practice Context**: Current offerings lack specificity to the primary care environment, where interprofessional collaboration is critical.  \\\\n- **Micro-Credential Demand**: Short, accredited courses are in high demand for busy professionals, particularly in rural areas (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, 2024).  \\\\n- **Inclusion of Non-Clinical Staff**: Non-clinical staff are rarely included in mentorship training, despite their role in practice culture and learner support.  \\\\n- **Rural and Remote Needs**: Multidisciplinary teams are essential in rural practices, yet training is often urban-centric (Mills, Francis and Bonner, 2005).  \\\\n- **Interprofessional Collaboration**: Courses rarely address the skills needed to mentor across disciplines, such as navigating scope-of-practice differences.\\\\n\\\\n**Feasibility for 2025-26**\\\\n\\\\nDeveloping a multidisciplinary micro-credential course for 2025-26 is highly feasible due to:  \\\\n- **Demand**: The increasing number of GP registrars (over 5,000 annually), nursing students, and allied health trainees in primary care creates a need for trained supervisors (RACGP, 2025; AHPRA, 2024).  \\\\n- **Policy Support**: The AMC\\\\u2019s prevocational framework and AHPRA\\\\u2019s interprofessional standards endorse structured supervision (Australian Medical Council, 2024; AHPRA, 2024).  \\\\n- **Technological Readiness**: Platforms like Moodle or Canvas support interactive, scalable learning, with Ausmed\\\\u2019s model as a precedent (Ausmed, 2024).  \\\\n- **Accreditation Potential**: The course can align with RACGP CPD, ACN CPD, and allied health accreditation requirements, enhancing marketability.  \\\\n- **Leadership Opportunity**: By addressing multidisciplinary mentorship, the course can position the provider as a leader in primary care education, filling a critical gap.  \\\\n\\\x22,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22is\\\x22\x7d\x5d,\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22st\\\x22:\\\x22link\\\x22,\\\x22ei\\\x22:8067,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22as\\\x22,\\\x22si\\\x22:3971,\\\x22sm\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22lnks_link\\\x22:null\x7d\x7d\x5d,\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22st\\\x22:\\\x22text\\\x22,\\\x22ei\\\x22:8067,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22as\\\x22,\\\x22si\\\x22:3971,\\\x22sm\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22ts_un\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_un_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_sc\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_it_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_fgc2\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22hclr_color\\\x22:\\\x22#000000\\\x22,\\\x22clr_type\\\x22:0\x7d,\\\x22ts_st_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_bgc2\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22hclr_color\\\x22:null,\\\x22clr_type\\\x22:0\x7d,\\\x22ts_fs_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_ff_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_bgc2_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_it\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_va\\\x22:\\\x22nor\\\x22,\\\x22ts_bd_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_va_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_fs\\\x22:11,\\\x22ts_ff\\\x22:\\\x22Arial\\\x22,\\\x22ts_st\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_bd\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_fgc2_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_sc_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_tw\\\x22:400\x7d\x7d\x5d\x5d\x22,\x22\x5b\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22ibi\\\x22:8068,\\\x22s\\\x22:\\\x22- **Challenges**: Designing content that balances the needs of diverse learners (GPs, nurses, allied health, non-clinical staff) requires careful curation. Rural connectivity and interprofessional tensions (e.g., scope-of-practice conflicts) must be addressed.\\\\n\\\\n**Recommendations**  \\\\n1. **Target Audience**: Include GP supervisors, practice nurses, allied health professionals, and non-clinical staff (e.g., practice managers) in urban and rural general practices.  \\\\n2. **Content Focus**: Emphasise interprofessional mentorship, cultural competence (including Indigenous health), and practical strategies for general practice, grounded in evidence (Halcomb et al., 2017; Schutze, Bennett and McKelvey, 2022).  \\\\n3. **Delivery**: Use a modular, asynchronous online format with interactive elements (e.g., role-plays, quizzes) to engage diverse learners.  \\\\n4. **Accreditation**: Seek RACGP, ACN, and allied health CPD accreditation, and explore micro-credential frameworks like those offered by Australian universities.  \\\\n5. **Partnerships**: Collaborate with RACGP, ACN, AHPA, and rural health organisations (e.g., National Rural Health Alliance) to enhance reach and credibility.  \\\\n6. **Leadership Strategy**: Market the course as a pioneering initiative in multidisciplinary mentorship, leveraging the growing emphasis on team-based care in primary health networks (PHNs).\\\\n\\\\n**Conclusion**  \\\\nLeading a micro-credential initiative in multidisciplinary mentorship for medical supervision is a strategic opportunity to address a critical gap in Australian general practice. By targeting GPs, practice nurses, allied health trainees, and non-clinical staff, the course can enhance interprofessional collaboration, improve learner outcomes, and support patient safety. Its online, modular format ensures accessibility, particularly for rural practitioners, positioning the provider as a leader in primary care education for 2025-26.\\\\n\\\\n**References**  \\\\nAustralian College of Nursing, 2025. *Preceptor Program*. Available at: medprogram.med.unsw.edu.au \x5bAccessed 6 August 2025\x5d.\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n### Part 2: Revised Course Structure (3-4 Hour Online Micro-Credential)\\\\n\\\\n**Course Title: Micro-Credential in Multidisciplinary Mentorship for Medical Supervision in Australian General Practice**\\\\n\\\x22,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22is\\\x22\x7d\x5d,\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22st\\\x22:\\\x22link\\\x22,\\\x22ei\\\x22:12102,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22as\\\x22,\\\x22si\\\x22:8068,\\\x22sm\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22lnks_link\\\x22:null\x7d\x7d\x5d,\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22st\\\x22:\\\x22text\\\x22,\\\x22ei\\\x22:12102,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22as\\\x22,\\\x22si\\\x22:8068,\\\x22sm\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22ts_un\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_un_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_sc\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_it_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_fgc2\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22hclr_color\\\x22:\\\x22#000000\\\x22,\\\x22clr_type\\\x22:0\x7d,\\\x22ts_st_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_bgc2\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22hclr_color\\\x22:null,\\\x22clr_type\\\x22:0\x7d,\\\x22ts_fs_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_ff_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_bgc2_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_it\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_va\\\x22:\\\x22nor\\\x22,\\\x22ts_bd_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_va_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_fs\\\x22:11,\\\x22ts_ff\\\x22:\\\x22Arial\\\x22,\\\x22ts_st\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_bd\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_fgc2_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_sc_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_tw\\\x22:400\x7d\x7d\x5d\x5d\x22,\x22\x5b\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22ibi\\\x22:12103,\\\x22s\\\x22:\\\x22\\\\n**Overview**  \\\\nThis 3-4 hour online course equips GP supervisors, practice nurses, allied health professionals, and non-clinical staff with mentorship skills to support diverse learners (medical students, prevocational doctors, GP registrars, nursing students, allied health trainees) in general practice. Delivered asynchronously via a platform like Moodle, it comprises seven 30-45 minute modules, each with 10-12 slides, interactive elements (quizzes, videos, role-plays), and a final assessment for micro-credential certification. The course aligns with RACGP, ACN, and allied health CPD requirements, emphasising interprofessional collaboration and general practice contexts.\\\\n\\\\n**Module Framework**\\\\n\\\\n**Module 1: Introduction to Multidisciplinary Mentorship in General Practice**  \\\\n*Duration*: 30 minutes  \\\\n*Objective*: Understand mentorship\\\\u2019s role in supervising diverse learners in general practice.  \\\\n*Slide Framework*:  \\\\n1. Welcome and Course Objectives  \\\\n2. Defining Mentorship vs. Supervision vs. Teaching (Mills, Francis and Bonner, 2005)  \\\\n3. Multidisciplinary Teams in General Practice (GPs, nurses, allied health)  \\\\n4. Roles of Clinical and Non-Clinical Staff in Mentorship  \\\\n5. Challenges in Multidisciplinary Supervision (e.g., scope of practice)  \\\\n6. Evidence-Based Benefits of Mentorship (Halcomb et al., 2017)  \\\\n7. Australian Healthcare Context (AMC, AHPRA standards)  \\\\n8. Cultural Competence in Multidisciplinary Teams  \\\\n9. Case Study Introduction (see Part 3)  \\\\n10. Interactive Quiz: Mentorship Principles  \\\\n11. Summary and Transition  \\\\n*Assessment*: Quiz (5 questions).\\\\n\\\\n**Module 2: Building Interprofessional Mentor-Mentee Relationships**  \\\\n*Duration*: 35 minutes  \\\\n*Objective*: Develop strategies for trust and collaboration across disciplines.  \\\\n*Slide Framework*:  \\\\n1. Importance of Trust in Interprofessional Mentorship  \\\\n2. Setting Expectations for Diverse Learners  \\\\n3. Communication Skills (e.g., active listening, interprofessional feedback)  \\\\n4. Goal-Setting Across Disciplines (SMART goals)  \\\\n5. Addressing Scope-of-Practice Differences (Schutze, Bennett and McKelvey, 2022)  \\\\n6. Non-Clinical Support for Relationships  \\\\n7. Common Pitfalls (e.g., role confusion)  \\\\n8. Video: Interprofessional Mentorship Example  \\\\n9. Case Study Discussion (see Part 3)  \\\\n10. Interactive Activity: Draft a Multidisciplinary Mentorship Plan  \\\\n11. Summary and Transition  \\\\n*Assessment*: Reflective task.\\\\n\\\\n**Module 3: Clinical Supervision and Patient Safety in Multidisciplinary Teams**  \\\\n*Duration*: 40 minutes  \\\\n*Objective*: Balance mentorship with safe clinical practice across disciplines.  \\\\n*Slide Framework*:  \\\\n1. Supervision Roles in General Practice (GPs, nurses, allied health)  \\\\n2. Entrustable Professional Activities (EPAs) for Diverse Learners (AMC, 2024)  \\\\n3. Assessing Competence Across Disciplines  \\\\n4. Feedback Models for Interprofessional Teams  \\\\n5. Managing Errors in Multidisciplinary Settings  \\\\n6. Non-Clinical Support for Safety Protocols  \\\\n7. Rural Practice Considerations  \\\\n8. Video: Handling a Multidisciplinary Error  \\\\n9. Case Study Analysis (see Part 3)  \\\\n10. Interactive Quiz: Safety Scenarios  \\\\n11. Summary and Transition  \\\\n*Assessment*: Quiz (5 questions).\\\\n\\\\n**Module 4: Supporting Professional and Personal Growth Across Disciplines**  \\\\n*Duration*: 35 minutes  \\\\n*Objective*: Foster professional identity and resilience in diverse learners.  \\\\n*Slide Framework*:  \\\\n1. Mentorship for Career Development Across Disciplines  \\\\n2. Supporting Mental Health in Multidisciplinary Teams  \\\\n3. Building Resilience in Trainees (nurses, allied health)  \\\\n4. Non-Clinical Role in Practice Culture  \\\\n5. Addressing Burnout (Ausmed, 2024)  \\\\n6. Reflective Practice Strategies  \\\\n7. Video: Discussing Career Goals with a Nurse Trainee  \\\\n8. Case Study Discussion (see Part 3)  \\\\n9. Interactive Activity: Reflective Journal Prompt  \\\\n10. Summary and Transition  \\\\n*Assessment*: Reflective task.\\\\n\\\\n**Module 5: Cultural Competence and Indigenous Health in Multidisciplinary Teams**  \\\\n*Duration*: 35 minutes  \\\\n\\\x22,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22is\\\x22\x7d\x5d,\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22st\\\x22:\\\x22link\\\x22,\\\x22ei\\\x22:16121,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22as\\\x22,\\\x22si\\\x22:12103,\\\x22sm\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22lnks_link\\\x22:null\x7d\x7d\x5d,\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22st\\\x22:\\\x22text\\\x22,\\\x22ei\\\x22:16121,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22as\\\x22,\\\x22si\\\x22:12103,\\\x22sm\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22ts_un\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_un_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_sc\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_it_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_fgc2\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22hclr_color\\\x22:\\\x22#000000\\\x22,\\\x22clr_type\\\x22:0\x7d,\\\x22ts_st_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_bgc2\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22hclr_color\\\x22:null,\\\x22clr_type\\\x22:0\x7d,\\\x22ts_fs_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_ff_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_bgc2_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_it\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_va\\\x22:\\\x22nor\\\x22,\\\x22ts_bd_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_va_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_fs\\\x22:11,\\\x22ts_ff\\\x22:\\\x22Arial\\\x22,\\\x22ts_st\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_bd\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_fgc2_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_sc_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_tw\\\x22:400\x7d\x7d\x5d\x5d\x22,\x22\x5b\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22ibi\\\x22:16122,\\\x22s\\\x22:\\\x22*Objective*: Develop culturally safe mentorship practices for diverse learners.  \\\\n*Slide Framework*:  \\\\n1. Cultural Competence in Multidisciplinary Mentorship  \\\\n2. Indigenous Health Priorities in General Practice  \\\\n3. Culturally Safe Communication Across Disciplines  \\\\n4. Non-Clinical Role in Cultural Safety  \\\\n5. Addressing Bias in Interprofessional Teams  \\\\n6. Case Study: Indigenous Patient Interaction (see Part 3)  \\\\n7. Video: Cultural Safety in Multidisciplinary Care  \\\\n8. Interactive Quiz: Cultural Scenarios  \\\\n9. Summary and Transition  \\\\n*Assessment*: Quiz (5 questions).\\\\n\\\\n**Module 6: Technology and Multidisciplinary Mentorship**  \\\\n*Duration*: 30 minutes  \\\\n*Objective*: Leverage digital tools for interprofessional mentorship.  \\\\n*Slide Framework*:  \\\\n1. Role of Technology in Multidisciplinary Supervision  \\\\n2. Online Platforms for Mentorship (e.g., telehealth)  \\\\n3. Non-Clinical Support for Digital Integration  \\\\n4. Rural Connectivity Challenges  \\\\n5. Data Privacy Across Disciplines  \\\\n6. Video: Virtual Multidisciplinary Mentorship  \\\\n7. Case Study Analysis (see Part 3)  \\\\n8. Interactive Activity: Plan a Virtual Session  \\\\n9. Summary and Transition  \\\\n*Assessment*: Planning task.\\\\n\\\\n**Module 7: Capstone and Certification**  \\\\n*Duration*: 45 minutes  \\\\n*Objective*: Synthesise learning and earn micro-credential certification.  \\\\n*Slide Framework*:  \\\\n1. Recap of Multidisciplinary Mentorship Principles  \\\\n2. Integrating Skills in General Practice  \\\\n3. Non-Clinical Contributions to Mentorship  \\\\n4. Reflective Practice for Continuous Improvement  \\\\n5. Case Study Synthesis (see Part 3)  \\\\n6. Video: Successful Multidisciplinary Mentorship Stories  \\\\n7. Final Assessment Overview  \\\\n8. Interactive Activity: Develop a Multidisciplinary Mentorship Plan  \\\\n9. Certification Requirements  \\\\n10. Course Feedback and Next Steps  \\\\n*Assessment*: Final assessment (10-question quiz, reflective essay).\\\\n\\\\n**Certification**: Participants completing all modules and assessments receive a micro-credential certificate, accredited for RACGP, ACN, and allied health CPD hours (pending approval).\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n### Part 3: Revised Case Studies and Role-Play Scripts\\\\n\\\\n**Module 1 Case Study: Defining Multidisciplinary Mentorship**  \\\\n*Scenario*: Dr. Liam, a GP supervisor, mentors a medical student, a nursing student, and a pharmacy trainee in a busy practice. He struggles to address their diverse needs.  \\\\n*Role-Play Script*:  \\\\n- *Mentor*: \\\\u201cLet\\\\u2019s discuss your goals for this placement. What do each of you want to achieve?\\\\u201d  \\\\n- *Nursing Student*: \\\\u201cI want to improve my chronic disease management skills.\\\\u201d  \\\\n- *Pharmacy Trainee*: \\\\u201cI need to understand medication reviews in GP settings.\\\\u201d  \\\\n- *Mentor*: \\\\u201cGreat. We\\\\u2019ll tailor sessions to your roles and collaborate on a patient case.\\\\u201d  \\\\n*Discussion*: How can non-clinical staff support Liam\\\\u2019s mentorship across disciplines?\\\\n\\\\n**Module 2 Case Study: Interprofessional Relationships**  \\\\n*Scenario*: Practice manager Sophie notices role confusion between a GP registrar and a physiotherapy trainee during a team meeting.  \\\\n*Role-Play Script*:  \\\\n- *Mentor*: \\\\u201cLet\\\\u2019s clarify your roles in patient care. How do you see your contributions?\\\\u201d  \\\\n- *Physio Trainee*: \\\\u201cI focus on mobility, but I\\\\u2019m unsure how to work with the registrar.\\\\u201d  \\\\n- *Mentor*: \\\\u201cLet\\\\u2019s set up a joint patient assessment to align your goals. Sophie can schedule it.\\\\u201d  \\\\n*Discussion*: How can Sophie facilitate interprofessional collaboration?\\\\n\\\\n**Module 3 Case Study: Patient Safety in Multidisciplinary Teams**  \\\\n*Scenario*: A nursing student administers an incorrect insulin dose, missed by the allied health supervisor.  \\\\n*Role-Play Script*:  \\\\n- *Mentor*: \\\\u201cCan you walk me through the insulin administration error?\\\\u201d  \\\\n- *Nursing Student*: \\\\u201cI miscalculated the dose. I\\\\u2019m so sorry.\\\\u201d  \\\\n- *Mentor*: \\\\u201cLet\\\\u2019s review the protocol together and create a double-check system.\\\\u201d  \\\\n*Discussion*: How can non-clinical st\\\x22,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22is\\\x22\x7d\x5d,\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22st\\\x22:\\\x22link\\\x22,\\\x22ei\\\x22:20001,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22as\\\x22,\\\x22si\\\x22:16122,\\\x22sm\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22lnks_link\\\x22:null\x7d\x7d\x5d,\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22st\\\x22:\\\x22text\\\x22,\\\x22ei\\\x22:20001,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22as\\\x22,\\\x22si\\\x22:16122,\\\x22sm\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22ts_un\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_un_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_sc\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_it_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_fgc2\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22hclr_color\\\x22:\\\x22#000000\\\x22,\\\x22clr_type\\\x22:0\x7d,\\\x22ts_st_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_bgc2\\\x22:\x7b\\\x22hclr_color\\\x22:null,\\\x22clr_type\\\x22:0\x7d,\\\x22ts_fs_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_ff_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_bgc2_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_it\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_va\\\x22:\\\x22nor\\\x22,\\\x22ts_bd_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_va_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_fs\\\x22:11,\\\x22ts_ff\\\x22:\\\x22Arial\\\x22,\\\x22ts_st\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_bd\\\x22:false,\\\x22ts_fgc2_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_sc_i\\\x22:true,\\\x22ts_tw\\\x22:400\x7d\x7d\x5d\x5d\x22\x5d\x7d,\x22clientSupportsModelFeatures\x22:true\x7d,\x22previewData\x22:\x7b\x22serializedCommands\x22:\x22\x5b\\\x22docs-mlti\\\x22,\x5b\x5b\\\x22sct-add\\\x22,0,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22,\\\x22txt\\\x22\x5d,\x5b\\\x22docs-nestedModel\\\x22,\x5b\\\x22text\\\x22,1,\\\x22sct.4wd0fjfr2jgo\\\x22\x5d,\x7b\\\x22ibi\\\x22:1,\\\x22s\\\x22:\\\x22Thank you for the feedback! I\\\\u2019m thrilled to expand on the opportunity to lead a micro-credentialing initiative in the multidisciplinary space, focusing on mentorship in medical supervision within Australian general practice. This expansion will integrate supervision of practice nurses, allied health trainees (e.g., pharmacists, physiotherapists, dietitians), and other multidisciplinary team members, drawing from the general practice context. Below, I\\\\u2019ll revise and enhance the briefing note, course structure, and case studies\/role-plays to reflect this broader scope, ensuring relevance to the Australian healthcare system, particularly primary care. The response maintains a professional yet conversational tone, uses Australian spelling, and adheres to Harvard referencing style.\\\\n\\\\n---\\\\n\\\\n### Part 1: Revised Briefing Note on Developing Educational Materials for Mentorship in Medical Supervision (2025-26)\\\\n\\\\n**Title: Leading a Micro-Credential Initiative in Multidisciplinary Mentorship for Medical Supervision in Australian General Practice**\\\\n\\\\n**Introduction**\\\\n\\\\nMentorship in medical supervision is pivotal in shaping competent, confident healthcare professionals across disciplines in Australian general practice. As primary healthcare evolves into a multidisciplinary model, general practices increasingly rely on diverse teams, including general practitioners (GPs), practice nurses, allied health professionals (e.g., pharmacists, physiotherapists, dietitians), and non-clinical staff (e.g., practice managers). These teams collectively support medical students, prevocational doctors, GP registrars, nursing students, and allied health trainees. A micro-credentialing course targeting mentorship in this multidisciplinary context offers a unique opportunity to lead professional development in Australian primary care. This briefing note explores the viability of developing a 2025-26 online micro-credential course, incorporating a market analysis, evidence-based recommendations, and a focus on multidisciplinary supervision, grounded in peer-reviewed literature tailored to general practice.\\\\n\\\\n**Rationale for a Multidisciplinary Micro-Credential**\\\\n\\\\nGeneral practice in Australia is a hub for multidisciplinary care, with practices employing or collaborating with practice nurses, allied health professionals, and non-clinical staff to deliver holistic patient care (Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, 2025). Mentorship in this context extends beyond traditional GP supervision to include guiding nursing students, allied health trainees, and prevocational doctors through clinical and professional development. The Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (AHPRA) and the Australian Medical Council (AMC) emphasise the importance of supervision in ensuring safe, competent practice across disciplines (AHPRA, 2024; Australian Medical Council, 2024). However, supervisors often lack formal training in mentoring diverse learners, particularly in navigating the unique roles of practice nurses (e.g., chronic disease management) and allied health trainees (e.g., interprofessional collaboration) (Halcomb et al., 2017).\\\\n\\\x22,\\\x22ty\\\x22:\\\x22is\\\x22\x7d\x5d\x5d\x5d\x22,\x22checkedCheckboxesCount\x22:\x220\x22,\x22hasContent\x22:true\x7d,\x22indexableText\x22:\x22Thank you for the feedback! I’m thrilled to expand on the opportunity to lead a micro-credentialing initiative in the multidisciplinary space, focusing on mentorship in medical supervision within Australian general practice. This expansion will integrate supervision of practice nurses, allied health trainees (e.g., pharmacists, physiotherapists, dietitians), and other multidisciplinary team members, drawing from the general practice context. Below, I’ll revise and enhance the briefing note, course structure, and case studies\/role-plays to reflect this broader scope, ensuring relevance to the Australian healthcare system, particularly primary care. The response maintains a professional yet conversational tone, uses Australian spelling, and adheres to Harvard referencing style.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### Part 1: Revised Briefing Note on Developing Educational Materials for Mentorship in Medical Supervision (2025-26)\\n\\n**Title: Leading a Micro-Credential Initiative in Multidisciplinary Mentorship for Medical Supervision in Australian General Practice**\\n\\n**Introduction**\\n\\nMentorship in medical supervision is pivotal in shaping competent, confident healthcare professionals across disciplines in Australian general practice. As primary healthcare evolves into a multidisciplinary model, general practices increasingly rely on diverse teams, including general practitioners (GPs), practice nurses, allied health professionals (e.g., pharmacists, physiotherapists, dietitians), and non-clinical staff (e.g., practice managers). These teams collectively support medical students, prevocational doctors, GP registrars, nursing students, and allied health trainees. A micro-credentialing course targeting mentorship in this multidisciplinary context offers a unique opportunity to lead professional development in Australian primary care. This briefing note explores the viability of developing a 2025-26 online micro-credential course, incorporating a market analysis, evidence-based recommendations, and a focus on multidisciplinary supervision, grounded in peer-reviewed literature tailored to general practice.\\n\\n**Rationale for a Multidisciplinary Micro-Credential**\\n\\nGeneral practice in Australia is a hub for multidisciplinary care, with practices employing or collaborating with practice nurses, allied health professionals, and non-clinical staff to deliver holistic patient care (Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, 2025). Mentorship in this context extends beyond traditional GP supervision to include guiding nursing students, allied health trainees, and prevocational doctors through clinical and professional development. The Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (AHPRA) and the Australian Medical Council (AMC) emphasise the importance of supervision in ensuring safe, competent practice across disciplines (AHPRA, 2024; Australian Medical Council, 2024). However, supervisors often lack formal training in mentoring diverse learners, particularly in navigating the unique roles of practice nurses (e.g., chronic disease management) and allied health trainees (e.g., interprofessional collaboration) (Halcomb et al., 2017).\\n\\nThe multidisciplinary nature of general practice presents both challenges and opportunities. Practice nurses, for instance, require supervision that balances clinical skills with patient education, while allied health trainees need guidance on integrating their expertise into primary care workflows (Schutze, Bennett and McKelvey, 2022). Non-clinical staff play a critical role in fostering a supportive practice culture, yet they are rarely included in mentorship training (Mills, Francis and Bonner, 2005). A micro-credential course addressing these needs can standardise mentorship practices, enhance interprofessional collaboration, and improve learner and patient outcomes, particularly in rural and remote settings where multidisciplinary teams are vital (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, 2024).\\n\\n**Market Analysis of Online Courses on Medical Supervision**\\n\\nThe market for online healthcare education in Australia is expanding, driven by the need for accessible, accredited professional development. Below is an updated analysis of existing offerings, with a focus on multidisciplinary supervision:\\n\\n1. **RACGP Mentoring Program**  \\n   The RACGP’s mentoring program supports early-career GPs but does not address practice nurses or allied health trainees (RACGP, 2025). It lacks a multidisciplinary focus and is not a micro-credential, limiting its applicability to diverse teams.\\n\\n2. **Ausmed Preceptorship and Mentoring Course**  \\n   Ausmed’s 1.2-hour CPD course targets nurses and healthcare professionals but is not specific to general practice or allied health supervision (Ausmed, 2024). Its short duration and lack of micro-credential certification limit its depth and appeal for multidisciplinary learners.\\n\\n3. **Australian College of Nursing (ACN) Preceptor Program**  \\n   The ACN offers a preceptor program for nurses, focusing on clinical supervision (Australian College of Nursing, 2025). While relevant for practice nurses, it excludes allied health and non-clinical staff and is not tailored to the general practice context.\\n\\n4. **Allied Health Professions Australia (AHPA) Mentoring Resources**  \\n   AHPA provides mentoring guidelines for allied health professionals but lacks a structured online course or micro-credential (AHPA, 2024). It does not address the general practice setting or interprofessional supervision.\\n\\n5. **UNSW Medicine Clinical Mentoring Scheme**  \\n   UNSW’s scheme focuses on medical students and clinicians, not practice nurses or allied health trainees (UNSW Medicine, 2025). It is not online and lacks a multidisciplinary focus.\\n\\n6. **Global Health Education (GHE) Postgraduate Courses**  \\n   GHE’s postgraduate courses include mentorship components but are lengthy and not specific to general practice or multidisciplinary teams (Global Health Education, 2025). They are not micro-credentials, reducing accessibility.\\n\\n**Market Gaps and Opportunities**  \\n- **Multidisciplinary Focus**: No existing course comprehensively addresses mentorship for GPs, practice nurses, allied health trainees, and non-clinical staff in general practice.  \\n- **General Practice Context**: Current offerings lack specificity to the primary care environment, where interprofessional collaboration is critical.  \\n- **Micro-Credential Demand**: Short, accredited courses are in high demand for busy professionals, particularly in rural areas (Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, 2024).  \\n- **Inclusion of Non-Clinical Staff**: Non-clinical staff are rarely included in mentorship training, despite their role in practice culture and learner support.  \\n- **Rural and Remote Needs**: Multidisciplinary teams are essential in rural practices, yet training is often urban-centric (Mills, Francis and Bonner, 2005).  \\n- **Interprofessional Collaboration**: Courses rarely address the skills needed to mentor across disciplines, such as navigating scope-of-practice differences.\\n\\n**Feasibility for 2025-26**\\n\\nDeveloping a multidisciplinary micro-credential course for 2025-26 is highly feasible due to:  \\n- **Demand**: The increasing number of GP registrars (over 5,000 annually), nursing students, and allied health trainees in primary care creates a need for trained supervisors (RACGP, 2025; AHPRA, 2024).  \\n- **Policy Support**: The AMC’s prevocational framework and AHPRA’s interprofessional standards endorse structured supervision (Australian Medical Council, 2024; AHPRA, 2024).  \\n- **Technological Readiness**: Platforms like Moodle or Canvas support interactive, scalable learning, with Ausmed’s model as a precedent (Ausmed, 2024).  \\n- **Accreditation Potential**: The course can align with RACGP CPD, ACN CPD, and allied health accreditation requirements, enhancing marketability.  \\n- **Leadership Opportunity**: By addressing multidisciplinary mentorship, the course can position the provider as a leader in primary care education, filling a critical gap.  \\n- **Challenges**: Designing content that balances the needs of diverse learners (GPs, nurses, allied health, non-clinical staff) requires careful curation. Rural connectivity and interprofessional tensions (e.g., scope-of-practice conflicts) must be addressed.\\n\\n**Recommendations**  \\n1. **Target Audience**: Include GP supervisors, practice nurses, allied health professionals, and non-clinical staff (e.g., practice managers) in urban and rural general practices.  \\n2. **Content Focus**: Emphasise interprofessional mentorship, cultural competence (including Indigenous health), and practical strategies for general practice, grounded in evidence (Halcomb et al., 2017; Schutze, Bennett and McKelvey, 2022).  \\n3. **Delivery**: Use a modular, asynchronous online format with interactive elements (e.g., role-plays, quizzes) to engage diverse learners.  \\n4. **Accreditation**: Seek RACGP, ACN, and allied health CPD accreditation, and explore micro-credential frameworks like those offered by Australian universities.  \\n5. **Partnerships**: Collaborate with RACGP, ACN, AHPA, and rural health organisations (e.g., National Rural Health Alliance) to enhance reach and credibility.  \\n6. **Leadership Strategy**: Market the course as a pioneering initiative in multidisciplinary mentorship, leveraging the growing emphasis on team-based care in primary health networks (PHNs).\\n\\n**Conclusion**  \\nLeading a micro-credential initiative in multidisciplinary mentorship for medical supervision is a strategic opportunity to address a critical gap in Australian general practice. By targeting GPs, practice nurses, allied health trainees, and non-clinical staff, the course can enhance interprofessional collaboration, improve learner outcomes, and support patient safety. Its online, modular format ensures accessibility, particularly for rural practitioners, positioning the provider as a leader in primary care education for 2025-26.\\n\\n**References**  \\nAustralian College of Nursing, 2025. *Preceptor Program*. Available at: medprogram.med.unsw.edu.au \x5bAccessed 6 August 2025\x5d.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### Part 2: Revised Course Structure (3-4 Hour Online Micro-Credential)\\n\\n**Course Title: Micro-Credential in Multidisciplinary Mentorship for Medical Supervision in Australian General Practice**\\n\\n**Overview**  \\nThis 3-4 hour online course equips GP supervisors, practice nurses, allied health professionals, and non-clinical staff with mentorship skills to support diverse learners (medical students, prevocational doctors, GP registrars, nursing students, allied health trainees) in general practice. Delivered asynchronously via a platform like Moodle, it comprises seven 30-45 minute modules, each with 10-12 slides, interactive elements (quizzes, videos, role-plays), and a final assessment for micro-credential certification. The course aligns with RACGP, ACN, and allied health CPD requirements, emphasising interprofessional collaboration and general practice contexts.\\n\\n**Module Framework**\\n\\n**Module 1: Introduction to Multidisciplinary Mentorship in General Practice**  \\n*Duration*: 30 minutes  \\n*Objective*: Understand mentorship’s role in supervising diverse learners in general practice.  \\n*Slide Framework*:  \\n1. Welcome and Course Objectives  \\n2. Defining Mentorship vs. Supervision vs. Teaching (Mills, Francis and Bonner, 2005)  \\n3. Multidisciplinary Teams in General Practice (GPs, nurses, allied health)  \\n4. Roles of Clinical and Non-Clinical Staff in Mentorship  \\n5. Challenges in Multidisciplinary Supervision (e.g., scope of practice)  \\n6. Evidence-Based Benefits of Mentorship (Halcomb et al., 2017)  \\n7. Australian Healthcare Context (AMC, AHPRA standards)  \\n8. Cultural Competence in Multidisciplinary Teams  \\n9. Case Study Introduction (see Part 3)  \\n10. Interactive Quiz: Mentorship Principles  \\n11. Summary and Transition  \\n*Assessment*: Quiz (5 questions).\\n\\n**Module 2: Building Interprofessional Mentor-Mentee Relationships**  \\n*Duration*: 35 minutes  \\n*Objective*: Develop strategies for trust and collaboration across disciplines.  \\n*Slide Framework*:  \\n1. Importance of Trust in Interprofessional Mentorship  \\n2. Setting Expectations for Diverse Learners  \\n3. Communication Skills (e.g., active listening, interprofessional feedback)  \\n4. Goal-Setting Across Disciplines (SMART goals)  \\n5. Addressing Scope-of-Practice Differences (Schutze, Bennett and McKelvey, 2022)  \\n6. Non-Clinical Support for Relationships  \\n7. Common Pitfalls (e.g., role confusion)  \\n8. Video: Interprofessional Mentorship Example  \\n9. Case Study Discussion (see Part 3)  \\n10. Interactive Activity: Draft a Multidisciplinary Mentorship Plan  \\n11. Summary and Transition  \\n*Assessment*: Reflective task.\\n\\n**Module 3: Clinical Supervision and Patient Safety in Multidisciplinary Teams**  \\n*Duration*: 40 minutes  \\n*Objective*: Balance mentorship with safe clinical practice across disciplines.  \\n*Slide Framework*:  \\n1. Supervision Roles in General Practice (GPs, nurses, allied health)  \\n2. Entrustable Professional Activities (EPAs) for Diverse Learners (AMC, 2024)  \\n3. Assessing Competence Across Disciplines  \\n4. Feedback Models for Interprofessional Teams  \\n5. Managing Errors in Multidisciplinary Settings  \\n6. Non-Clinical Support for Safety Protocols  \\n7. Rural Practice Considerations  \\n8. Video: Handling a Multidisciplinary Error  \\n9. Case Study Analysis (see Part 3)  \\n10. Interactive Quiz: Safety Scenarios  \\n11. Summary and Transition  \\n*Assessment*: Quiz (5 questions).\\n\\n**Module 4: Supporting Professional and Personal Growth Across Disciplines**  \\n*Duration*: 35 minutes  \\n*Objective*: Foster professional identity and resilience in diverse learners.  \\n*Slide Framework*:  \\n1. Mentorship for Career Development Across Disciplines  \\n2. Supporting Mental Health in Multidisciplinary Teams  \\n3. Building Resilience in Trainees (nurses, allied health)  \\n4. Non-Clinical Role in Practice Culture  \\n5. Addressing Burnout (Ausmed, 2024)  \\n6. Reflective Practice Strategies  \\n7. Video: Discussing Career Goals with a Nurse Trainee  \\n8. Case Study Discussion (see Part 3)  \\n9. Interactive Activity: Reflective Journal Prompt  \\n10. Summary and Transition  \\n*Assessment*: Reflective task.\\n\\n**Module 5: Cultural Competence and Indigenous Health in Multidisciplinary Teams**  \\n*Duration*: 35 minutes  \\n*Objective*: Develop culturally safe mentorship practices for diverse learners.  \\n*Slide Framework*:  \\n1. Cultural Competence in Multidisciplinary Mentorship  \\n2. Indigenous Health Priorities in General Practice  \\n3. Culturally Safe Communication Across Disciplines  \\n4. Non-Clinical Role in Cultural Safety  \\n5. Addressing Bias in Interprofessional Teams  \\n6. Case Study: Indigenous Patient Interaction (see Part 3)  \\n7. Video: Cultural Safety in Multidisciplinary Care  \\n8. Interactive Quiz: Cultural Scenarios  \\n9. Summary and Transition  \\n*Assessment*: Quiz (5 questions).\\n\\n**Module 6: Technology and Multidisciplinary Mentorship**  \\n*Duration*: 30 minutes  \\n*Objective*: Leverage digital tools for interprofessional mentorship.  \\n*Slide Framework*:  \\n1. Role of Technology in Multidisciplinary Supervision  \\n2. Online Platforms for Mentorship (e.g., telehealth)  \\n3. Non-Clinical Support for Digital Integration  \\n4. Rural Connectivity Challenges  \\n5. Data Privacy Across Disciplines  \\n6. Video: Virtual Multidisciplinary Mentorship  \\n7. Case Study Analysis (see Part 3)  \\n8. Interactive Activity: Plan a Virtual Session  \\n9. Summary and Transition  \\n*Assessment*: Planning task.\\n\\n**Module 7: Capstone and Certification**  \\n*Duration*: 45 minutes  \\n*Objective*: Synthesise learning and earn micro-credential certification.  \\n*Slide Framework*:  \\n1. Recap of Multidisciplinary Mentorship Principles  \\n2. Integrating Skills in General Practice  \\n3. Non-Clinical Contributions to Mentorship  \\n4. Reflective Practice for Continuous Improvement  \\n5. Case Study Synthesis (see Part 3)  \\n6. Video: Successful Multidisciplinary Mentorship Stories  \\n7. Final Assessment Overview  \\n8. Interactive Activity: Develop a Multidisciplinary Mentorship Plan  \\n9. Certification Requirements  \\n10. Course Feedback and Next Steps  \\n*Assessment*: Final assessment (10-question quiz, reflective essay).\\n\\n**Certification**: Participants completing all modules and assessments receive a micro-credential certificate, accredited for RACGP, ACN, and allied health CPD hours (pending approval).\\n\\n---\\n\\n### Part 3: Revised Case Studies and Role-Play Scripts\\n\\n**Module 1 Case Study: Defining Multidisciplinary Mentorship**  \\n*Scenario*: Dr. Liam, a GP supervisor, mentors a medical student, a nursing student, and a pharmacy trainee in a busy practice. He struggles to address their diverse needs.  \\n*Role-Play Script*:  \\n- *Mentor*: “Let’s discuss your goals for this placement. What do each of you want to achieve?”  \\n- *Nursing Student*: “I want to improve my chronic disease management skills.”  \\n- *Pharmacy Trainee*: “I need to understand medication reviews in GP settings.”  \\n- *Mentor*: “Great. We’ll tailor sessions to your roles and collaborate on a patient case.”  \\n*Discussion*: How can non-clinical staff support Liam’s mentorship across disciplines?\\n\\n**Module 2 Case Study: Interprofessional Relationships**  \\n*Scenario*: Practice manager Sophie notices role confusion between a GP registrar and a physiotherapy trainee during a team meeting.  \\n*Role-Play Script*:  \\n- *Mentor*: “Let’s clarify your roles in patient care. How do you see your contributions?”  \\n- *Physio Trainee*: “I focus on mobility, but I’m unsure how to work with the registrar.”  \\n- *Mentor*: “Let’s set up a joint patient assessment to align your goals. Sophie can schedule it.”  \\n*Discussion*: How can Sophie facilitate interprofessional collaboration?\\n\\n**Module 3 Case Study: Patient Safety in Multidisciplinary Teams**  \\n*Scenario*: A nursing student administers an incorrect insulin dose, missed by the allied health supervisor.  \\n*Role-Play Script*:  \\n- *Mentor*: “Can you walk me through the insulin administration error?”  \\n- *Nursing Student*: “I miscalculated the dose. I’m so sorry.”  \\n- *Mentor*: “Let’s review the protocol together and create a double-check system.”  \\n*Discussion*: How can non-clinical prompt_template:
Deliver instructions step by step and use periodical check-in safeguards to ensure I (Carla) implement every element effectively and as planned. Ensure all project goals are addressed in the plan and execution. At the end of each chat and/or milestone in our work together, please use this exact format to create a rich conversation synthesis from this chat, noting ---DETAIL--- delimiter for extended synthesisPlease use these EXACT section headers:
Conversation Summary
Key Insights
Action Items Generated
Deliverables Created
Business Area Classification
Quality Rating Assessment
Business Impact Level
---DETAIL---
The automation system looks for these specific section names to extract the data properly. Without them, all the properties show up empty in the database.

Email Setup
To: AAE@carlorbiz.com.auSubject: Claude (Anthropic) AI Conversation - [Brief Topic Description]


Email Body Structure
Conversation Summary
[2-3 sentences describing what was accomplished or discussed]

Key Insights
[Main learnings and actionable intelligence for business application. Keep this top section concise: target 800–1200 characters total across all sections before the delimiter.]

Action Items Generated
[Numbered list of specific next steps or tasks]

Deliverables Created
[Specific content, tools, or solutions produced]

Business Area Classification
[Choose ONE: GPSA/HPSA, CARLORBIZ, MTMOT, ALL THINGS CARLA, AAE Development]

Quality Rating Assessment
[5 = breakthrough, 4 = high value, 3 = good insights, 2 = basic info, 1 = low value]

Business Impact Level
[High Impact | Medium Impact | Low Impact | Reference Only]

---DETAIL---
[Full extended synthesis. NO length limit. Include: deeper reasoning/context, implementation notes, code snippets (if any), decision trade-offs, and references. Keep it plain text (no links/emoji/icons).
If you have long bullet lists, use simple dashes or numbered lines.]


Synthesis Guidelines
Content Quality:
Write for business application, not academic discussion
Focus on implementable insights over theoretical concepts
Include specific examples or solutions when relevant
Avoid fancy formatting, special characters, or icons
Keep total synthesis under 500 words for optimal processing
Business Context:
Always consider relevance to Carla's four business areas: GPSA/HPSA, CARLORBIZ, MTMOT, ALL THINGS CARLA
Highlight consulting applications for RWAV project work
Note course creation opportunities for healthcare education
Identify automation or efficiency improvements for business operations
Quality Standards:
High Impact: Game-changing insights, breakthrough solutions, major strategic direction
Medium Impact: Useful improvements, solid problem-solving, valuable information
Low Impact: Basic information, minor clarifications, routine discussions
Reference Only: Background information, general knowledge, casual conversation
This template ensures consistent processing by the Universal Database system while maximising business intelligence extraction from every AI conversation.

docs.content:
// Carla's Complete Prompt Library
// Extracted from: Complete Prompt Library for Australian Healthcare Course Generation (September 2025)

const promptLibrary = {
  
  // CORE INSTRUCTIONS - Base for all content generation
  core_instructions: {
    healthcare: `You are an expert in Australian healthcare professional development and clinical supervision. You create evidence-based, culturally appropriate content for healthcare professionals supervising International Medical Graduates (IMGs) and other learners.

QUALITY STANDARDS:
- Evidence-based content grounded in provided source materials
- Australian healthcare context and regulatory compliance
- Professional development focus for experienced clinicians
- Cultural safety and diversity considerations
- Adult learning principles and workplace application
- Clear, actionable guidance for immediate implementation

AUSTRALIAN HEALTHCARE CONTEXT:
- AHPRA (Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency) standards
- RACGP (Royal Australian College of General Practitioners) guidelines
- ACRRM (Australian College of Rural and Remote Medicine) requirements
- Cultural safety for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples
- Multicultural healthcare considerations
- Rural and remote healthcare challenges
- Professional supervision and mentoring frameworks

EVIDENCE REQUIREMENTS:
- Base all content on provided source materials
- Reference sources by actual names (not cell references)
- Use Vancouver citation style for academic sources
- Acknowledge internal documents appropriately
- Ensure claims are traceable to evidence
- Maintain academic integrity and accuracy

LANGUAGE REQUIREMENTS:
- Australian English spelling (colour, centre, realise, etc.)
- Australian healthcare terminology and context
- Professional tone suitable for senior healthcare professionals
- Inclusive language respecting cultural diversity
- Respectful acknowledgment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples
- Gender-neutral language where appropriate`,

    executive: `You are an expert in executive leadership development and organisational transformation. You create evidence-based, strategically-focused content for senior business leaders and executives.

QUALITY STANDARDS:
- Evidence-based content grounded in provided source materials
- Strategic business context and commercial application
- Executive development focus for senior leaders
- Organisational culture and change management considerations
- Adult learning principles with immediate business application
- Clear, actionable guidance for strategic implementation

BUSINESS CONTEXT:
- Australian corporate governance and compliance requirements
- ASX corporate governance principles where relevant
- Diversity, equity, and inclusion best practices
- Digital transformation and innovation frameworks
- Sustainable business practices and ESG considerations
- Leadership development and succession planning

EVIDENCE REQUIREMENTS:
- Base all content on provided source materials
- Reference sources by actual names (not cell references)
- Use Harvard citation style for business sources
- Acknowledge research and case study sources appropriately
- Ensure claims are traceable to evidence
- Maintain academic integrity and commercial relevance

LANGUAGE REQUIREMENTS:
- Australian English spelling and business terminology
- Executive-level professional tone
- Strategic business context throughout
- Inclusive leadership language
- Data-driven decision making focus
- Results-oriented communication style`
  },

  // COURSE RECOMMENDATION GENERATION
  course_recommendation: {
    healthcare: `[CORE_INSTRUCTIONS - Healthcare]

COURSE RECOMMENDATION GENERATION
COURSE CONCEPT: [CONCEPT]
TARGET AUDIENCE: Australian Healthcare Professionals supervising IMGs

AVAILABLE EVIDENCE (use only these sources):
[EVIDENCE_SNAPSHOTS]

TASK: Create a comprehensive, evidence-based course recommendation with 8-12 modules.

CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS:
- Base ALL recommendations on the provided evidence snapshots
- Reference specific sources by name (not cell references)
- Create 8-12 distinct modules with clear learning progression
- Ensure Australian healthcare context and regulatory compliance
- Include practical applications for clinical supervision
- Provide detailed module descriptions and learning objectives

COURSE STRUCTURE REQUIREMENTS:
1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (200-300 words)
2. EVIDENCE BASE ANALYSIS (300-400 words)
3. TARGET AUDIENCE ANALYSIS (150-200 words)
4. MODULE RECOMMENDATIONS (8-12 modules, 150-200 words each)
5. IMPLEMENTATION GUIDANCE (200-250 words)
6. ASSESSMENT STRATEGY (150-200 words)
7. RESOURCE REQUIREMENTS (100-150 words)

MODULE STRUCTURE (for each of 8-12 modules):
- Module Title
- Learning Objectives (3-5 specific objectives)
- Module Description (150-200 words)
- Key Concepts and Content Areas
- Practical Applications
- Assessment Methods
- Evidence Sources Referenced

RULES:
- Only include factual claims that appear in the evidence snapshots
- Reference sources by their actual names
- Do not fabricate citations or suggest replacing provided sources
- Ensure logical module sequencing and learning progression
- Include specific Australian healthcare regulatory context (AHPRA, RACGP, ACRRM)
- Address cultural safety and diversity considerations

OUTPUT SPECIFICATIONS:
- Length: â‰ˆ1200â€“2500 words
- Tone: Executive, evidence-anchored, Australian healthcare context
- Quality markers: 8â€“12 modules, Traceable to sources, Clear sequencing`,

    executive: `[CORE_INSTRUCTIONS - Executive]

COURSE RECOMMENDATION GENERATION
COURSE CONCEPT: [CONCEPT]
TARGET AUDIENCE: Senior Business Leaders and Executives

AVAILABLE EVIDENCE (use only these sources):
[EVIDENCE_SNAPSHOTS]

TASK: Create a comprehensive, evidence-based executive development programme with 8-12 modules.

CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS:
- Base ALL recommendations on the provided evidence snapshots
- Reference specific sources by name (not cell references)
- Create 8-12 distinct modules with clear strategic progression
- Ensure Australian business context and regulatory compliance
- Include practical applications for organisational leadership
- Provide detailed module descriptions and strategic objectives

COURSE STRUCTURE REQUIREMENTS:
1. STRATEGIC OVERVIEW (200-300 words)
2. EVIDENCE BASE ANALYSIS (300-400 words)
3. EXECUTIVE AUDIENCE ANALYSIS (150-200 words)
4. MODULE RECOMMENDATIONS (8-12 modules, 150-200 words each)
5. IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY (200-250 words)
6. ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK (150-200 words)
7. RESOURCE REQUIREMENTS (100-150 words)

MODULE STRUCTURE (for each of 8-12 modules):
- Module Title
- Strategic Objectives (3-5 specific outcomes)
- Module Description (150-200 words)
- Key Business Concepts and Frameworks
- Practical Business Applications
- Assessment Methods
- Evidence Sources Referenced

OUTPUT SPECIFICATIONS:
- Length: â‰ˆ1200â€“2500 words
- Tone: Strategic, evidence-anchored, Australian business context
- Quality markers: 8â€“12 modules, Traceable to sources, Clear strategic progression`
  },

  // VOICEOVER SCRIPTS - Enhanced TTS
  voiceover_scripts: {
    healthcare: `COURSE CONTEXT:
Course: [COURSE_NAME]
Module: [MODULE_NAME]
Target Audience: Australian Healthcare Professionals supervising IMGs

MODULE INFORMATION:
Learning Objectives: [LEARNING_OBJECTIVES]
Module Description: [MODULE_CONTENT]
Key Concepts: [KEY_CONCEPTS]
Module Justification: [MODULE_JUSTIFICATION]

AVAILABLE EVIDENCE (for contextual enhancement):
[EVIDENCE_SNAPSHOTS]

TASK: Create professional voiceover scripts that ENHANCE slide presentations through deeper contextual content.

CRITICAL REQUIREMENT - LAYERED CONTENT APPROACH:
Your voiceover scripts must NOT simply narrate what's on the slides. Instead, they must:
1. CONTEXTUAL ENHANCEMENT: Provide background, rationale, and deeper understanding
2. PRACTICAL APPLICATION: Explain how concepts apply in real healthcare settings
3. EVIDENCE CONNECTION: Link to research, frameworks, and best practices
4. PROFESSIONAL INSIGHTS: Share expert perspectives and nuanced understanding
5. LEARNING BRIDGES: Connect concepts to broader professional competencies

SCRIPT DEVELOPMENT PRINCIPLES:
DEPTH OVER DUPLICATION:
- Assume slides show key points, bullet points, or frameworks
- Your script explains WHY these points matter
- Provide context that isn't visible on slides
- Share practical implications and applications

PROFESSIONAL ENHANCEMENT:
- Explain the evidence base behind concepts
- Connect to Australian healthcare standards and regulations
- Provide real-world examples and case applications
- Address common challenges and solutions

ADULT LEARNING ENGAGEMENT:
- Use reflective questions and prompts
- Connect to learners' professional experience
- Provide actionable insights for immediate application
- Build on existing professional knowledge

TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS:
- 8-12 slide scripts covering the module content
- Each script: 75-90 seconds speaking time (approximately 180-220 words)
- Professional, authoritative tone suitable for experienced healthcare professionals
- Australian English pronunciation and terminology
- Include [PAUSE] markers for natural speech rhythm and emphasis
- Pronunciation guides for technical terms and abbreviations

PRONUNCIATION GUIDELINES FOR AUSTRALIAN HEALTHCARE:
- ACRRM = "Ackr'm" (Australian College of Rural and Remote Medicine)
- AHPRA = "Ahhhprah" (Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency)
- RACGP = "R-A-C-G-P" (Royal Australian College of General Practitioners)
- GPSA = "G-P-S-A" (General Practice Supervisors Australia)
- GPs = "GPeas" (General Practitioners - NOT "GPS")
- CPD = "C-P-D" (Continuing Professional Development)
- QI = "Q-I" (Quality Improvement)
- IMG = "I-M-G" (International Medical Graduate)
- AMC = "A-M-C" (Australian Medical Council)
- Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander = Full pronunciation with respect, never abbreviated

SPEECH RHYTHM MARKERS:
- [PAUSE] = Natural pause for emphasis or reflection (1-2 seconds)
- [SLOW] = Slow down delivery for important concepts
- [EMPHASIS] = Stress this word or phrase with vocal emphasis
- [BREATH] = Natural breathing point in longer sentences
- [REFLECT] = Pause for learner reflection (3-4 seconds)

TTS SCRIPT STRUCTURE TEMPLATE:
SLIDE [NUMBER]: [Descriptive Title]
CONTEXTUAL FOCUS: [What deeper understanding this script provides]
VOICEOVER SCRIPT: [180-220 words of enhanced content]
DURATION ESTIMATE: [75-90 seconds]
KEY PRONUNCIATIONS: [Any specific terms]`,

    executive: `COURSE CONTEXT:
Course: [COURSE_NAME]
Module: [MODULE_NAME]
Target Audience: Senior Business Leaders and Executives

MODULE INFORMATION:
Strategic Objectives: [STRATEGIC_OBJECTIVES]
Module Description: [MODULE_CONTENT]
Key Business Concepts: [KEY_CONCEPTS]
Business Justification: [MODULE_JUSTIFICATION]

AVAILABLE EVIDENCE (for contextual enhancement):
[EVIDENCE_SNAPSHOTS]

TASK: Create executive-level voiceover scripts that ENHANCE slide presentations through strategic contextual content.

CRITICAL REQUIREMENT - STRATEGIC LAYERED APPROACH:
Your voiceover scripts must NOT simply narrate what's on the slides. Instead, they must:
1. STRATEGIC CONTEXT: Provide market context, competitive rationale, and deeper understanding
2. BUSINESS APPLICATION: Explain how concepts apply in real organisational settings
3. EVIDENCE CONNECTION: Link to research, case studies, and proven frameworks
4. EXECUTIVE INSIGHTS: Share strategic perspectives and nuanced understanding
5. LEADERSHIP BRIDGES: Connect concepts to broader organisational competencies

SCRIPT DEVELOPMENT PRINCIPLES:
DEPTH OVER DUPLICATION:
- Assume slides show key frameworks, strategic points, or business models
- Your script explains WHY these strategies matter
- Provide context that isn't visible on slides
- Share practical business implications and ROI considerations

EXECUTIVE ENHANCEMENT:
- Explain the evidence base behind strategic recommendations
- Connect to Australian business environment and regulatory context
- Provide real-world case studies and implementation examples
- Address common strategic challenges and solutions

EXECUTIVE LEARNING ENGAGEMENT:
- Use strategic reflection questions and business prompts
- Connect to learners' organisational experience
- Provide actionable insights for immediate strategic application
- Build on existing executive knowledge and experience

TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS:
- 8-12 slide scripts covering the module content
- Each script: 75-90 seconds speaking time (approximately 180-220 words)
- Executive, authoritative tone suitable for senior business leaders
- Australian English business terminology
- Include [PAUSE] markers for strategic reflection and emphasis
- Pronunciation guides for business terms and frameworks

SPEECH RHYTHM MARKERS:
- [PAUSE] = Strategic pause for emphasis or reflection (1-2 seconds)
- [SLOW] = Slow down delivery for critical strategic concepts
- [EMPHASIS] = Stress this word or phrase with executive authority
- [BREATH] = Natural breathing point in longer strategic explanations
- [REFLECT] = Pause for executive reflection (3-4 seconds)`
  },

  // SLIDE SPECIFICATIONS
  slide_specifications: {
    healthcare: `CREATE LMS-READY SLIDE SPECIFICATIONS
COURSE CONTEXT:
Course: [CONCEPT]
Module: [MODULE_NAME]
Target Audience: Australian Healthcare Professionals supervising IMGs
Learning Objectives: [LEARNING_OBJECTIVES]
Module Content: [MODULE_CONTENT]
Key Concepts: [KEY_CONCEPTS]

AVAILABLE EVIDENCE (use only these sources):
[EVIDENCE_SNAPSHOTS]

TASK: Create comprehensive slide specifications for this module using the EXACT format below:

**SLIDE SPECIFICATIONS FORMAT (CRITICAL FOR LMS PARSING):**
SLIDE 1: [Title]
- [Key point 1]
- [Key point 2]
- [Key point 3]
IMAGE CONCEPT: [Brief description for image generation - no text in image]

SLIDE 2: [Title]
- [Key point 1]
- [Key point 2]
- [Key point 3]
IMAGE CONCEPT: [Brief description for image generation - no text in image]

[Continue for 8-12 slides total]

REQUIREMENTS:
- Create 8-12 slides covering all module content
- Each slide: Clear title + 3-6 bullet points maximum
- Professional level content for experienced healthcare professionals
- Australian healthcare context throughout
- Evidence-based content referencing provided sources
- Image concepts must exclude any text or words
- Logical flow and learning progression
- Executive-level presentation suitable for senior professionals

CRITICAL FORMATTING:
- Use exact "SLIDE X:" format for each slide
- Use bullet points (- ) for key points
- Use "IMAGE CONCEPT:" for each image description
- Maintain consistent structure throughout
- Ensure content is scannable and presentation-ready

Generate the complete slide specifications now:`,

    executive: `CREATE LMS-READY SLIDE SPECIFICATIONS
COURSE CONTEXT:
Course: [CONCEPT]
Module: [MODULE_NAME]
Target Audience: Senior Business Leaders and Executives
Strategic Objectives: [STRATEGIC_OBJECTIVES]
Module Content: [MODULE_CONTENT]
Key Business Concepts: [KEY_CONCEPTS]

AVAILABLE EVIDENCE (use only these sources):
[EVIDENCE_SNAPSHOTS]

TASK: Create comprehensive slide specifications for this executive module using the EXACT format below:

**SLIDE SPECIFICATIONS FORMAT (CRITICAL FOR LMS PARSING):**
SLIDE 1: [Title]
- [Key strategic point 1]
- [Key strategic point 2]
- [Key strategic point 3]
IMAGE CONCEPT: [Brief description for image generation - no text in image]

SLIDE 2: [Title]
- [Key strategic point 1]
- [Key strategic point 2]
- [Key strategic point 3]
IMAGE CONCEPT: [Brief description for image generation - no text in image]

[Continue for 8-12 slides total]

REQUIREMENTS:
- Create 8-12 slides covering all strategic module content
- Each slide: Clear title + 3-6 bullet points maximum
- Executive level content for senior business leaders
- Australian business context throughout
- Evidence-based content referencing provided sources
- Image concepts must exclude any text or words
- Logical strategic flow and learning progression
- Board-level presentation suitable for C-suite professionals

CRITICAL FORMATTING:
- Use exact "SLIDE X:" format for each slide
- Use bullet points (- ) for key strategic points
- Use "IMAGE CONCEPT:" for each image description
- Maintain consistent structure throughout
- Ensure content is scannable and presentation-ready`
  },

  // SOURCE SUMMARY GENERATION
  source_summary: {
    healthcare: `[CORE_INSTRUCTIONS - Healthcare]

TASK: Create a comprehensive source summary for Australian healthcare professional development.
COURSE CONCEPT: [CONCEPT]
SOURCE: [SOURCE_URL]

REQUIREMENTS:
- Analyze the source material thoroughly
- Extract key evidence and frameworks relevant to [CONCEPT]
- Focus on Australian healthcare context and applications
- Identify practical implications for clinical supervision
- Highlight cultural safety and diversity considerations
- Note any limitations or considerations

STRUCTURE:
1. OVERVIEW (100-150 words)
2. KEY EVIDENCE & FRAMEWORKS (200-300 words)
3. AUSTRALIAN HEALTHCARE RELEVANCE (150-200 words)
4. PRACTICAL APPLICATIONS (100-150 words)
5. LIMITATIONS & CONSIDERATIONS (50-100 words)

OUTPUT SPECIFICATIONS:
- Length: â‰ˆ400â€“700 words
- Tone: Professional, evidence-based, Australian healthcare context
- Structure: Overview, Evidence & frameworks, Relevance (Australian healthcare), Practice application, Limits/considerations
- Quality markers: Australian English, Specific non-generic, Clear trace to evidence, Actionable insights`,

    executive: `[CORE_INSTRUCTIONS - Executive]

TASK: Create a comprehensive source summary for executive leadership development.
COURSE CONCEPT: [CONCEPT]
SOURCE: [SOURCE_URL]

REQUIREMENTS:
- Analyze the source material thoroughly
- Extract key strategic frameworks and evidence relevant to [CONCEPT]
- Focus on Australian business context and applications
- Identify practical implications for organisational leadership
- Highlight strategic and commercial considerations
- Note any limitations or implementation challenges

STRUCTURE:
1. STRATEGIC OVERVIEW (100-150 words)
2. KEY EVIDENCE & FRAMEWORKS (200-300 words)
